attributes.title: Tokio Marine: Big And Beautiful
summary: Tokio Marine is Japan’s top insurer with strong global diversification, but faces challenges integrating international acquisitions and managing catastrophe risk.
The regulator's push to unwind cross-shareholdings gives Tokio $10bn to redeploy, presenting both growth opportunities and risks of poor acquisitions.
Recent results show solid growth and upward revisions, but the current valuation at 15x earnings is high for targeted 8% EPS growth.
I view Tokio Marine as a long-term quality play, but rate it a Hold; I’d buy below $35 or at a forward PE of 12x.

attributes.content:
Tokio Marine Holdings trading OTC (OTCPK:TKOMY) (OTCPK:TKOMF) and on the Tokyo stock exchange (TYO:8766) is the leading composite insurance company in Japan, and has, over years of acquisition, established a large global footprint.

Tokio Marine is the largest company you might have never heard of, its 6.2 trillion JPY in turnover is around $43 billion.

Let's have a look at what is behind this giant of an insurance company.

The Business & History

Tokio Marine operates through four segments:

  • Domestic Non-Life Insurance Business.
  • Domestic Life Insurance Business.
  • International Insurance Business.
  • Financial and Other Businesses.

Having been active in Japan since its foundation in 1879, Tokio Marine has established an international footprint over the years by multiple acquisitions.

It's important to understand the history of Japanese companies, however global their footprint today, in order to evaluate the company's strategic outlook.

First The Foundation

Tokio Marine was formed as part of one of the Japanese business conglomerates 'Zaibatsu' that developed during the late 19th and early 20th century. These Zaibatsu are the roots of all the powerful Japanese companies that still exist today. Tokio Marine was part of the Yasuda zaibatsu. While these were formally dismantled by the Allies after WW2, Japanese companies continued with a 'Keiretsu' model, which quietly replaced the formal corporations with cross shareholdings that continued the entrenched business relationships. Key shareholdings of Tokio Marine include Toyota, Mitsubishi, Suzuki, as well as their competitors.

The Japanese regulator, the FSA, has been pushing the Japanese insurers to unload these cross shareholdings, and in 2024, this came to a head, as reported here, with an order from the FSA for the big four Japanese insurers to unload $43bn of such cross shareholdings. (As a sidebar, you might have noticed Warren Buffett has recently invested in Japanese industrials. In the insurance industry, Berkshire Hathaway is where you go when you have a problem. I'd speculate that Berkshire has made mostly off market deals which have allowed large divestments without creating stock price volatility.)

Then The Walls

With a very slow-growing Japanese economy, and an overall profitable domestic business, Tokio has had to look outside Japan to deploy capital and generate growth. They have made several acquisitions over the years:

  • Kiln - A Lloyds of London P&C Insurer and Reinsurer in 2007
  • Philadelphia - a U.S. P&C Insurer in 2018
  • Delphi in 2011 - Delphi is an employee benefits carrier
  • Houston Casualty 'HCC' in 2015 - HCC is a U.S. based global Casualty and Specialty underwriter
  • PURE Insurance in 2019 - PURE is a high net worth home and contents carrier (think rich folks with homes near the coast)

Through these acquisitions, Tokio Marine now writes as much international business and Japanese business. This strategic diversification makes a lot of sense. Japan is a low growth market, and Japan has a large exposure to both earthquakes - Tokyo, in the shadow of Mt Fuji pictured above, is in an active seismic area, and tropical cyclones which can impact large areas of the country in a single event.

However, their chosen acquisitions have also dogged the company with issues over the years, from general poor underwriting results at Kiln, to the current challenge of Commercial Real Estate investments at Delphi.

Diversification means stepping out of your competence zone, and this can be a painful process. Kiln wrote much heavier exposures in its US and international business than Tokio saw in Japan, and Delphi writes business with much longer duration liabilities, where the asset management and reserving are crucial.

I mention this in the context of a big strategic challenge that faces Tokio Marine.

The Strategic Dilemma

Tokio now has to find a way to re-invest the capital freed up by selling off the cross shareholdings discussed above. As reported by industry source the Insurance Journal, Tokio now has $10bn of cash burning a hole in its pocket. It needs to find a way to deploy this capital while avoiding the pain that can be caused by 'di-worsification' - growing via the acquisition of substandard assets.

So, in a nutshell, Tokio faces a big opportunity, in terms of being able to recycle funds from passive, low growth investments into acquiring insurance businesses that can drive real growth. However, there is also a risk, in that buying the wrong asset can generate major problems too.

So far, there has been little news of this. Let's have a look at the performance of the stock and the existing business.

Investor Returns

Over the last five years, Tokio Marine has performed well versus peers. Here I chose non-Japanese global peers, Allianz (OTCPK:ALIZY) AIG (AIG) and market favorite Chubb (CB). While all have done well, Tokio wins by a nose in terms of total return.

Business Performance

On Feb 14th, Tokio, which follows the April 1st Japan financial year, reported Q3 results. They were pretty good, with positive results in the main property casualty business slightly offset by poor performance in the small life and health business.

Overall, the P&C business grew in Japan by 3.9%, and International by 6.4%. Management revised the full-year outlook for international from 7% to 7.8%.

Net income estimates were also revised upwards by about 14%. The slides are quite busy, and have a huge amount of detail, but aren't an easy read, so I am being very selective here. If you want the whole story, you can see the detail for yourself.

This performance promises acceleration of the steady EPS growth for the last few years. The latest projection relates to $7.6bn USD, up nearly 12% from $6.8bn reported end March 2024.

The company is moving towards its long-term targets, for 8% growth in EPS, and a 14% ROE. You can see the scale of the cross shareholding sales in realizing capital gains as a one off is worth 6% of ROE, incremental to the 14% target.

Valuation

On a price to earnings basis, Tokio is with the pack, albeit at a slight premium.

AIG trails, in my mind, mainly due to a long-term investor 'hangover' from the financial crisis (but that's a story for another day.)

Tokio is also the most expensive from a price to book value basis.

Risks

  • A key risk to Tokio is Natural Catastrophe and climate risk. While much of the international business is casualty & specialty, Tokio has very large exposure to Japanese Earthquake, Tsunami and Wind/Flood. PURE is also a property underwriter, and high-value homes tend to be in risky locations near the coast. Kiln remains a big property cat writer
  • Acquisition and integration risk, as discussed above.
  • CRE valuation risk - while reserves seem to be stable, this has been a painful topic and downside risk remains.
  • Casualty reserving in the US business. US casualty reserves have been deteriorating across the market, offset by favorable workers compensation development. Delphi has introduced challenges on the asset side, but has probably helped the underwriting results with positive worker compensation reserve releases. These are now drying up across the industry.

Conclusion & My Position

I see Tokio Marine as a best-in-class performer in its home market. I am hopeful in the long term that unwinding the cross shareholdings will result in increasing prices in the Japanese market. However, this will require a generation of management to turnover. Change is a slow process in Japan.

In the international business, I think that it is more of a sum of the parts than a cohesive entity. There are some good businesses in there, and with $10bn to spend, there is opportunity.

Overall, I see Tokio Marine as a solid long-term play. However, I do see the current valuation at 15x to be on the high side for a company that targets 8% EPS growth in the P&C insurance business. I would be a buyer at a forward PE of 12x or below $35. I rate Tokio Marine as a Hold.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

attributes.bio: The author has an honours degree in economics and politics with a focus on economic development. With 36 years of experience in executive management he has extensive knowledge of insurance/reinsurance, Global and Asia Pacific markets, climate change and ESG. He invests in his personal capacity.
